author: Grace Ebert
title: An Uncanny Postcard Fit for the Era of Climate Catastrophe
text:
From left: Sunset, Cyanometer, and Air Pollution postcards An Uncanny Postcard Fit for the Era of Climate Catastrophe May 7, 2025 Grace Ebert Bookmark Depending on the day, you might look to the sky and see a sea of pale blue or a radiant sunset creeping toward the horizon. If you’re in a major metropolitan area, though, you might also be met with the characteristic red-brown haze of smog.
Berlin-based artist Macarena Ruiz-Tagle is behind the vibrant Cyanometer and Sunset postcards we’ve featured on Colossal (and that have sold out in our shop several times). But she also created a third version designed for those not-so-bright days.
Tiananmen Square, Beijing (November 2013). Photo by Macarena Ruiz-Tagle The World Health Organization estimates that 99 percent of people on Earth breathe unsafe air, making Ruiz-Tagle’s Air Pollution postcard perhaps the most fitting for our era of climate catastrophe. While a stark contrast to the brilliant blues, yellows, and oranges of the other two, this design is awash in pale pinks and grays to match that of a gloomy, and even soiled, atmosphere. Like the others, the idea is to hold the work up to the sky and mark the corresponding hue before dropping it in the mail.
The interactive card shifts in meaning depending on whether the opening reveals a misty fog or air thick with chemicals, and it’s part of a growing movement to track climate data in a tangible, grassroots manner. “Separating the visual delight of being immersed in a cloud from the intoxicating reality of breathing heavily polluted air, the postcard evokes both the smog that engulfs global cities and the ethereal beauty of fog,” the artist writes. “In its mesmerizing aesthetic ambiguity, the work sustains a space for contemplation within our troubled atmosphere.”
Find all three postcards in the Colossal Shop , and explore more of Ruiz-Tagle’s work on her website .
Air Pollution postcard

author: Silvia M.C.Senette
title: Il regalo delle tre sorelle Vecchietti: l'eredità di 1 milione a poveri, parrocchie, scuole e vigili del fuoco | Corriere.it
text: Il regalo delle tre sorelle Vecchietti: l'eredità di 1 milione a poveri, parrocchie, scuole e vigili del fuoco Le tre sorelle trentine, due maestre, hanno fatto tre testamenti fotocopia a beneficio delle realtà che amavano È un regalo di Natale che attraversa i confini regionali quello legato all'eredità di un'anziana e generosa insegnante e che unisce in una storia commovente Lombardia e Trentino. La notizia emerge grazie al sindaco di Valmadrera, un piccolo centro nel cuore della Lombardia con poco più di 11mila abitanti: Antonio Rusconi, il primo cittadino, ha infatti condiviso sulla sua pagina Facebook un messaggio toccante che collega la sua comunità a Trento. Il merito va alla generosità della maestra Jolanda Vecchietti, icona indimenticata della formazione e della bontà. Scomparsa tre anni fa dopo aver superato i 101 anni di età, la longeva insegnante ha lasciato in eredità una donazione espressamente finalizzata all'istituzione di due borse di studio, del valore di 1.500 euro ciascuna e a cadenza annuale, destinate alle scuole primarie di Valmadrera e Malgrate. Un nobile gesto di cui la piccola comunità lombarda è venuta a conoscenza dopo che la Fondazione Crosina Sartori Cloch di Trento - destinataria di una parte di altri beni lasciati dalla docente - ha contattato nei giorni scorsi il sindaco Rusconi svelando il lascito e il testamento della maestra. La storia è però ancora più allargata e coinvolge anche le altre due sorelle Vecchietti: Ada e Lidia, anche loro scomparse negli scorsi anni, in un toccante racconto tutto al femminile che attraversa confini e connette le regioni. E che ha al centro un'eredità milionaria Le tre sorelle Lidia, insegnante, è morta diversi anni fa. Nel settembre 2020 si è spenta Jolanda: anche lei maestra, è deceduta a 101 anni in una casa di riposo trentina; non prima di salutare alcuni suoi ex alunni che erano venuti a salutarla in occasione del centenario. L'ultima ad andarsene, a febbraio 2022, è stata Ada, alla soglia dei cent'anni. I loro testamenti, simili come fotocopie, rivelano un'eredità milionaria - nel complesso sarebbe di oltre un milione - composta da immobili, beni di interesse storico e notevoli disponibilità finanziarie. «Prego di voler fare istituire due borse di studio da euro 1.500 ciascuna (entrambe annue) da assegnare tramite i rispettivi sindaci a Valmadrera e a Malgrate, dove abbiamo insegnato», scriveva nel suo testamento la maestra Jolanda. Parte della sua eredità era destinata alla fondazione trentina, mentre le volontà che riguardano altre generose porzioni di patrimonio sono state disposte a beneficio di alcune parrocchie, ai vigili del fuoco, a un centro studi e a una casa di riposo e a realtà che si occupano di aiutare persone in stati ti indigenza; tutti situati tra Trento e Malè. La dedica della sua ex alunna (oggi assessore) Il sindaco Rusconi ha espresso via social la sua gratitudine per questo inatteso dono di Natale, sottolineando «la generosa volontà della maestra Jolanda che per noi ha scritto una vera favola di Natale». Un incontro tra i sindaci di Valmadrera e Malgrate, assieme ali vertici della fondazione trentina, è stato programmato per definire i criteri di assegnazione delle borse di studio. Nel frattempo la memoria dell'insegnante trentina resta viva nei suoi ex alunni; tra questi, l'assessora al Sociale di Valmadrera, Rita Bosisio. «Nel suo cuore, da sempre, restavano i volti di chi, durante gli anni di insegnamento, aveva educato e istruito con profonda dedizione - ha rivelato -. Le loro fotografie erano custodite con cura e affetto dalla maestra in un grande libro con nomi e date. E tuttora noi allievi la ricordiamo con profonda gratitudine, ammirazione e riconoscenza: era una maestra moderna e innovativa, bravissima. Qualcuna di noi è diventata maestra seguendo proprio il suo esempio di vita: ci faceva un po' da mamma e le dobbiamo molto». La carriera, poi il ritiro Nativa di Trento, dove è deceduta il 17 settembre del 2020 a 101 anni, Jolanda Vecchietti era giunta a Valmadrera nel 1958 dopo una carriera scolastica iniziata in Dalmazia, proseguita in Istria, a Trento e nel Lecchese, a Oggiono, dal 1950 al 1958. A Valmadrera ha insegnato dal 1958 al 1974 quando, per accudire la madre malata, ha dovuto "con immenso dispiacere" lasciare la scuola. Ritiratasi a Trento, ha collaborato con il Centro studi della Val di Sole che ha pubblicato due suoi libri: "L'affresco" e "Diario Dalmata". La newsletter del Corriere del Trentino Se vuoi restare aggiornato sulle notizie del Trentino iscriviti gratis alla newsletter del Corriere del Trentino. Arriva tutti i giorni direttamente nella tua casella di posta alle 12. Basta cliccare [qui](https://www.corriere.it/newsletter/?theme=60). 29 dicembre 2023 © RIPRODUZIONE RISERVATA

author: Gustavo Rangel
title: Robots created with human cells help neuron growth - Últimas Noticias
text: A team from Tufts and Harvard universities have managed to develop small biological robots from human tracheal cells that can move across a surface and stimulate the growth of neurons, at least in a laboratory dish. According to the research published on the portal of the [Tufts University](https://now.tufts.edu/2023/11/30/scientists-build-tiny-biological-robots-human-cells), which range in size from the width of a human hair to the tip of a sharp pencil, were made to self-assemble and were shown to have a remarkable healing effect on other cells. According to the portal, the discovery is a starting point for researchers' vision of using patient-derived biobots as new therapeutic tools for regeneration, healing and treating diseases. In the study, also replicated by the Minister of Science and Technology, [Gabriela Jimenez](https://twitter.com/Gabrielasjr/status/1740087268998574212?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1740087268998574212%7Ctwgr%5E02d2c381e434e6cdd5f6dfcb305f0bcb719e70df%7Ctwcon%5Es1_c10&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fultimasnoticias.com.ve%2Fwp-admin%2Fpost.php%3Fpost%3D2696325action%3Dedit), the authors discovered that the cells could not only create new multicellular shapes, but were also able to move in different ways on a surface of human neurons grown in a laboratory dish, and stimulate new growth to fill gaps caused by injury. . Likewise, the study suggests that among the advantages of using human cells is the possibility of building robots from the patient's own cells to carry out therapeutic work without the risk of triggering an immune response or requiring immunosuppressants.

author: Elizabeth Gregerson
title: AI tool trained on radiologist eye movement
text:
Researchers have trained an AI framework to read chest X-rays by mimicking the eye movements of radiologists, according to a paper published Dec. 12 in Artificial Intelligence in Medicine.
The framework is called ItpCtrl-AI, which stands for interpretable and controllable artificial intelligence, and is "transparent and highly accurate," according to a Feb. 25 news release from Fayetteville-based University of Arkansas.
A heat map was created from recordings of radiologists' eye movements as they reviewed chest X-rays. The heat map was then used to teach the AI tool where to search for abnormalities, the release said.
The researchers are now working with Houston-based University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center to train ItpCtrl-AI on CT scan interpretation.
Read the full study here.

organizations.name: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

author: N/A
title: US Senate Chaplain Criticized For Offering Up Prayers For Those Mourning Iranian President
text:
US Senate Chaplain
Barry Black responded to criticism after he offered up a prayer for Iranian people “who mourn the death of their president.” Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi was killed in a helicopter crash on May 19, along with several other officials. The exact cause of the crash remains unknown. Black’s prayer received criticism, as Raisi was also known as “the Butcher of Tehran,” having been instrumental in the murder of as many as 5,000 political prisoners in 1988. The Fulcrum compared Black’s prayer “to praying for the Germans who mourned the death of Hitler, or the Russians who mourned the death of Stalin, or the Chinese who mourned the death of Mao, etc., etc.”
Speaking to
CBN News, Black stated he felt compelled to show compassion for the Iranian people as they mourned their president. “That same Christ, when crucified, the first words from His lips were words that said, ‘Forgive them. They know not what they do.’ He was praying for His executioners,” said Black. He added that Jesus “not only admonished that we pray even for enemies, but He demonstrated it as He was being crucified for those who nailed Him to the cross.” He described his decision as an act of obedience. “I am basically doing what my boss, Jesus, has commissioned me to do. [Christ] is the model. He prayed in the upper room when one of His own was about to betray Him. He was about to be betrayed, and then He washed His betrayer’s feet. I just felt that, as a Christian preacher, I was filled with compassion for the Iranian people I saw on TV. There were people that were crying out to their God, that this accident, they didn’t have clarity about,” he said. Black isn’t alone in offering condolences to the Iranian people. The UN, NATO, and the US State Department offered official condolences, to the criticism of many.
While Raisi
was buried four days after the crash, with large crowds being shown mourning, his critics and those who were impacted by his political executions may have less of an avenue to express their derision. Esmat Vatanparast, who lost 11 family members during the political executions, celebrated Raisi’s death. “My happiness has no limits. Today is a beautiful day for the people of Iran,” she told RFE/RL’s Radio Farda, a station which seeks to bring uncensored news to the people of Iran. Vatanparast fled to Sweden after her family members’ deaths. Dadban, an Iranian group of lawyers that represents Iranian political prisoners, wrote on X that it had received reports of Iranians being told to take down posts and sign celebrating the death of Raisi. Iranian expatriates can be seen in various other countries celebrating Raisi’s death. “I’m happy at this moment because a symbol of murder is gone,” former political prisoner Mehdi Aslani told Radio Farda. “I would be lying if I said the news of the death of this executioner did not bring me joy.”

author: @CalSB
title: Butler Named To Preseason All-ACC Team
text: Kelley Cox/klcfotos Butler named to preseason All-ACC team SB1/23/2025 12:01 PM | By: Cal Athletics Butler Named To Preseason All-ACC Team Cal Picked To Finish Sixth in Preseason Coaches Poll California infielder Elon Butler was named to the 2025 ACC Softball Preseason All-ACC Team, the conference office announced Thursday afternoon. Butler returns for her third season in a Golden Bear uniform after a stellar sophomore campaign, in which she was named a NFCA All-American (second team) in addition to earning spots on the NFCA All-Region First Team and All-Pac-12 Second Team. She led the team in home runs (17), RBIs (44), total bases (117) and slugging percentage (.760) while being third in runs (37), hits (54) and batting average (.351) in 2024. Cal, which will play its inaugural season as a member of the ACC, was picked to finish sixth in the league by the conference's coaches, earning 130 points in the preseason poll. Duke was the favorite with 193 points and 11 first-place votes, followed by Florida State with 183 points and four first-place votes. Virginia Tech (165), Stanford (143) and Virginia (140) rounded out the top five. Five ACC teams were ranked in ESPN.com/USA Softball Preseason Top 25, tied for the second-most of all conferences. Duke led the conference at No. 8, followed by Florida State (No. 12), Virginia Tech (No. 18), Cal (No. 21) and Stanford (No. 22). 2025 ACC Softball Preseason Coaches Poll 1. Duke - 193 points (11 first-place votes) 2. Florida State - 183 points (4 first-place votes) 3. Virginia Tech - 165 points 4. Stanford - 143 points 5. Virginia - 140 points 6. Cal - 130 points 7. Clemson - 126 points 8. Georgia Tech - 87 points 9. North Carolina - 85 points 10. Louisville - 73 points 11. Notre Dame - 72 points 12. Boston College - 66 points 13. NC State - 65 points 14. Syracuse - 31 points 15. Pitt - 16 points 2025 Softball Preseason All-ACC Team Elon Butler, California, INF Maddie Moore, Clemson, INF Aminah Vega, Duke, INF Jaysoni Beachum, Florida State, INF Jade Hylton, Virginia, INF D'auna Jennings, Duke, OF Jahni Kerr, Florida State, OF Alex Coleman, North Carolina, OF Emily Jones, Stanford, OF Cassidy Curd, Duke, P Eden Bigham, Virginia, P Emma Lemley, Virginia Tech, P Michaela Edenfield, Florida State, C Cori McMillan, Virginia Tech, DP/UTIL STAY POSTED For complete coverage of Cal softball, please follow the Bears on X/Twitter (CalSB), Instagram (CalSB) and Facebook (Facebook.com/CalSoftball). Print Friendly Version

author: 新京报
title: 沙尘笼罩青海格尔木能见度仅数米|青海省_新浪财经_新浪网
text:
转自：新京报我们视频
【#沙尘笼罩青海格尔木能见度仅数米#】#青海局地出现大风强沙尘暴天气# 5月7日，甘肃、青海部分地区出现大风、强沙尘暴天气，青海格尔木沙尘暴形成沙墙缓慢推进，天空逐步呈现出红褐色，街道里的能见度逐步降低，车辆打开应急灯后缓慢通行。格尔木市市民岳先生说，前后半个多小时，天气就发生了明显的变化，出现沙尘后自己呛得不行，能见度也就几米。7日，甘肃敦煌月牙泉景区因大风沙尘持续，景区暂停开放。8日20时至9日20时，甘肃省局地仍有4至5级风，并伴有浮尘天气。（记者：马骏 制作：王子轩）
